header_summary:
The release of Bitcoin Core version 30.0 introduces a suite of new features, bug fixes, performance enhancements, and updated translations, emphasizing security with the end of maintenance for versions 27.x and older. Significant updates include policy adjustments such as a limit on legacy signature operations and an increase in the data carrier size for OP_RETURN outputs, alongside improvements in network and mempool management to bolster against denial-of-service attacks. The upgrade also introduces a unified `bitcoin` command line tool and reinstates support for external signing on Windows, among other refinements aimed at improving user accessibility and interaction with the software. For more details and to download the new version, users can visit [Bitcoin Core's official website](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-30.0/).

In parallel, Bitcoin Guard is unveiled as a novel security measure designed to protect Bitcoin users from physical attacks by increasing the risk for attackers and reducing potential rewards. This project introduces a lightweight signaling protocol within a Bitcoin address that allows users to lock their wallets in an emergency, effectively preventing unauthorized transactions. Bitcoin Guard's comprehensive approach includes mobile and desktop applications, integration with third-party services for emergency alerts, and detailed technical specifications available for review [here](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/introducing-bitcoin-guard/2049).

On another front, B-SSL emerges as an innovative system aimed at advancing Bitcoin security and management, addressing the critical issue of potential key loss in non-custodial wallets. The B-SSL framework proposes a dual-component solution catering to both institutions and individual users, featuring joint custody coordination and a sovereign vault with human fail-safes. This system seeks to enhance the safety and usability of digital currency storage and transactions, representing a significant step forward in cryptocurrency wallet design and management. Further discussion and technical details on B-SSL can be accessed [here](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/concept-review-b-ssl-bitcoin-secure-signing-layer-covenant-free-vault-model-using-taproot-csv-and-cltv/2047/3).

recent_posts.title: Introducing Bitcoin Guard
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Guard enhances Bitcoin security, aiming to favor victims over attackers through advanced measures.
- It introduces a protocol allowing users to lock wallets in emergencies, supported on various platforms.
- Demonstrated effectiveness via an Electrum fork, it offers prototypes and detailed documentation for user engagement.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core v30.0 Released
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core v30.0 brings new features, bug fixes, performance boosts, and updated translations.
- Version 30.0 ends maintenance for versions 27.x and older, encouraging users to upgrade.
- Key updates include a new `bitcoin` command line tool, increased `-datacarriersize`, and the transition to Qt 6 for the GUI.

recent_posts.title: Concept Review: B-SSL (Bitcoin Secure Signing Layer) — Covenant-Free Vault Model Using Taproot, CSV, and CLTV

- B-SSL aims to improve Bitcoin security and user control, preventing key loss.
- It introduces mint-005 for joint custody and a sovereign vault for individuals and companies.
- This innovation could redefine cryptocurrency storage and transaction security standards.

active_posts.title: On (in)ability to embed data into Schnorr
authors: On (in)ability to embed data into Schnorr waxwing/ AdamISZ
active_posts.summary:
- AdamISZ explores embedding data within Schnorr signatures, questioning its security without revealing keys.
- The analysis concludes that secure data embedding compromises private key integrity, impacting blockchain UTXO security.
- AdamISZ encourages critique, offering the research for public discussion on GitHub, highlighting privacy-security balance challenges.

active_posts.title: Sharing block templates
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin nodes and miners have adopted new mempool policies, improving network efficiency.
- Compact block relay has significantly reduced block propagation times, decreasing orphan rates.
- Alternative solutions like weak blocks and template sharing enhance network robustness and transaction privacy.

active_posts.title: Response to Pieter Wuille's StackExchange Answer Re: Nuking the Opreturn Filter
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin's fee estimation process is fraught with complexities and uncertainties.
- Efforts at standardizing mempools to predict miner actions are deemed futile and potentially harmful.
- A call for adapting to Bitcoin's inherent transaction variabilities, focusing on broader network-wide heuristics.

active_posts.title: Eclipsing Bitcoin Nodes with BGP Interception Attacks
active_posts.summary:
- A stealthier BGP hijacking method exposes significant Bitcoin network vulnerabilities, enabling eclipse attacks.
- Attackers can manipulate BGP routes to intercept Bitcoin traffic, using BGP communities for stealth.
- Mitigations include rotating peers, using dynamic ports, and prioritizing RPKI-protected peers for defense.

today_in_history_posts.title: BIP 2 revival and rework
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- An individual suggests modifying BIP licensing to prioritize "Share alike" over "Attribution."- CC0 is recommended as the ideal license for BIPs, with MIT/BSD or CC-BY as alternatives.
- BIP 2 may proceed soon, allowing but not recommending restrictive licenses for BIPs.

today_in_history_posts.title: Single channel on mobile clients
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Multiple phone channels for payments pose risks and user decision dilemmas.
- Users prefer simplicity over managing payment channels and capacities.
- Solutions include educating users on balance intricacies or restructuring channel balances.

today_in_history_posts.title: CVE-2024-38365 public disclosure (btcd `FindAndDelete` bug)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Niklas Gögge and Antoine Poinsot discovered a significant flaw in Btcd software versions before 0.24.2.
- Their investigation led to a bug bounty award and a coordinated fix introduced in version 0.24.2.
- The flaw's disclosure and resolution process involved CVE assignments, a covert fix, and community notification by September 20, 2024.
